(5) The President may, by order, abolish the Administrative Tribunal when he is satisfied that its continued existence is not necessary. (6) Every order made under this article shall, as soon as may be after it is made, be laid before each House of Parliament.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Establishment of Central University in Andhra Pradesh

amendments.description: Inserted Article 371E to provide for the establishment of a Central University in Andhra Pradesh.
amendments.updated_text: Parliament may by law provide for the establishment of a University in the State of Andhra Pradesh.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Special provisions with respect to the State of Sikkim

amendments.description: Inserted Article 371F to provide special provisions for the State of Sikkim upon its integration into India as a state.
amendments.updated_text: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution,— (a) the Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim shall consist of not less than thirty members; (b) as from the date of commencement of the Constitution (Thirty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1975 (hereafter in this article referred to as the appointed day)— (i) the Assembly for Sikkim formed as a result of the elections held in Sikkim in April, 1974 with thirty-two members elected in the said elections (hereinafter referred to as the sitting members) shall be deemed to be the Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim duly constituted under this Constitution; (ii) the sitting members shall be deemed to be the members of the Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim duly elected under this Constitution; and (iii) the said Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim shall exercise the powers and perform the functions of the Legislative Assembly of a State under this Constitution; (c) in the case of the Assembly deemed to be the Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim under clause (b), the references to the period of five years in clause (1) of article 172 shall be construed as references to a period of four years and the said period of four years shall be deemed to commence from the appointed day; (d) until other provisions are made by Parliament by law, there shall be allotted to the State of Sikkim one seat in the House of the People and the State of Sikkim shall form one parliamentary constituency to be called the Sikkim parliamentary constituency; (e) the representative of the State of Sikkim in the House of the People in existence on the appointed day shall be elected by the members of the Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim; (f) Parliament may, for the purpose of protecting the rights and interests of the different sections of the population of Sikkim make provision for the number of seats in the Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim which may be filled by candidates belonging to such sections and for the delimitation of the assembly constituencies from which candidates belonging to such sections alone may stand for election to the Legislative Assembly of the State of Sikkim; (g) the Governor of Sikkim shall have special responsibility for peace and for an equitable arrangement for ensuring the social and economic advancement of different sections of the population of Sikkim and in the discharge of his special responsibility under this clause, the Governor of Sikkim shall, subject to such directions as the President may, from time to time, deem fit to issue, act in his discretion; (h) all property and assets (whether within or outside the territories comprised in the State of Sikkim) which immediately before the appointed day were vested in the Government of Sikkim or in any other authority or in any person for the purposes of the Government of Sikkim shall, as from the appointed day, vest in the Government of the State of Sikkim; (i) the High Court functioning as such immediately before the appointed day in the territories comprised in the State of Sikkim shall, on and from the appointed day, be deemed to be the High Court for the State of Sikkim; (j) all courts of civil, criminal and revenue jurisdiction, all authorities and all officers, judicial, executive and ministerial, throughout the territory of the State of Sikkim shall continue on and from the appointed day to exercise their respective functions subject to the provisions of this Constitution; (k) all laws in force immediately before the appointed day in the territories comprised in the State of Sikkim or any part thereof shall continue to be in force therein until amended or repealed by a competent Legislature or other competent authority; (l) for the purpose of facilitating the application of any such law as is referred to in clause (k) in relation to the administration of the State of Sikkim and for the purpose of bringing the provisions of any such law into accord with the provisions of this Constitution, the President may, within two years from the appointed day, by order, make such adaptations and modifications of the law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient, and thereupon, every such law shall have effect subject to the adaptations and modifications so made, and any such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court of law; (m) neither the Supreme Court nor any other court shall have jurisdiction in respect of any dispute or other matter arising out of any treaty, agreement, engagement or other similar instrument relating to Sikkim which was entered into or executed before the appointed day and to which the Government of India or any of its predecessor Governments was a party, but nothing in this clause shall be construed to derogate from the provisions of article 143; (n) the President may, by public notification, extend with such restrictions or modifications as he thinks fit to the State of Sikkim any enactment which is in force in a State in India at the date of the notification; (o) if any difficulty arises in giving effect to any of the foregoing provisions of this article, the President may, by order, do anything (including any adaptation or modification of any other article) which appears to him to be necessary for the purpose of removing that difficulty: Provided that no such order shall be made after the expiry of two years from the appointed day; (p) all things done and all actions taken in or in relation to the State of Sikkim or the territories comprised therein during the period commencing on the appointed day and ending immediately before the date on which the Constitution (Thirty-sixth Amendment) Act, 1975, receives the assent of the President shall, in so far as they are in conformity with the provisions of this Constitution, be deemed for all purposes to have been validly done or taken under this Constitution.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Special provision with respect to the State of Mizoram

amendments.description: Inserted Article 371G to provide special provisions for the State of Mizoram, protecting Mizo customary laws and religious practices.
amendments.updated_text: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution,— (a) no Act of Parliament in respect of— (i) religious or social practices of the Mizos, (ii) Mizo customary law and procedure, (iii) administration of civil and criminal justice involving decisions according to Mizo customary law, (iv) ownership and transfer of land, shall apply to the State of Mizoram unless the Legislative Assembly of the State of Mizoram by a resolution so decides: Provided that nothing in this clause shall apply to any Central Act in force in the Union territory of Mizoram immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Fifty-third Amendment) Act, 1986; (b) the Legislative Assembly of the State of Mizoram shall consist of not less than forty members.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Special provision with respect to the State of Arunachal Pradesh

amendments.description: Inserted Article 371H to provide special provisions for the State of Arunachal Pradesh, including special responsibilities for the Governor.
amendments.updated_text: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution,— (a) the Governor of Arunachal Pradesh shall have special responsibility with respect to law and order in the State of Arunachal Pradesh and in the discharge of his functions in relation thereto, the Governor shall, after consulting the Council of Ministers, exercise his individual judgment as to the action to be taken: Provided that if any question arises whether any matter is or is not a matter as respects which the Governor is under this clause required to act in the exercise of his individual judgment, the decision of the Governor in his discretion shall be final, and the validity of anything done by the Governor shall not be called in question on the ground that he ought or ought not to have acted in the exercise of his individual judgment: Provided further that if the President on receipt of a report from the Governor or otherwise is satisfied that it is no longer necessary for the Governor to have special responsibility with respect to law and order in the State of Arunachal Pradesh, he may by order direct that the Governor shall cease to have such responsibility with effect from such date as may be specified in the order; (b) the Legislative Assembly of the State of Arunachal Pradesh shall consist of not less than thirty members.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Special provision with respect to the State of Goa

amendments.description: Inserted Article 371I to provide a special provision for the Legislative Assembly of the State of Goa.
amendments.updated_text: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Goa shall consist of not less than thirty members.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Special provisions with respect to the State of Karnataka

amendments.description: Inserted Article 371J to provide special provisions for the Hyderabad-Karnataka region of Karnataka for development and equitable opportunities.
amendments.updated_text: Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution, the President may, by order made with respect to the State of Karnataka, provide for any special responsibility of the Governor for— (a) establishment of a separate development board for Hyderabad-Karnataka region with the provision that a report on the working of such board will be placed each year before the State Legislative Assembly; (b) equitable allocation of funds for developmental expenditure over the said region, subject to the requirements of the State as a whole; and (c) equitable opportunities and facilities for the people belonging to the said region in matters of public employment, education and vocational training, subject to the requirements of the State as a whole.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Continuance in force of existing laws and their adaptation
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) Notwithstanding the repeal by this Constitution of the enactments referred to in article 395 but subject to the other provisions of this Constitution, all the law in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall continue in force therein until altered or repealed or amended by a competent Legislature or other competent authority. (2) For the purpose of bringing the provisions of any law in force in the territory of India into accord with the provisions of this Constitution, the President may by order make such adaptations and modifications of such law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient, and provide that the law shall, as from such date as may be specified in the order, have effect subject to the adaptations and modifications so made, and any such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court of law. (3) Nothing in clause (2) shall be deemed— (a) to empower the President to make any adaptation or modification of any law after the expiration of two years from the commencement of this Constitution; or (b) to prevent any competent Legislature or other competent authority from repealing or amending any law adapted or modified by the President under the said clause.

amendments.description: Amended Article 372 to extend the period for presidential adaptations of existing laws from two years to three years.
amendments.updated_text: (1) Notwithstanding the repeal by this Constitution of the enactments referred to in article 395 but subject to the other provisions of this Constitution, all the law in force in the territory of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall continue in force therein until altered or repealed or amended by a competent Legislature or other competent authority. (2) For the purpose of bringing the provisions of any law in force in the territory of India into accord with the provisions of this Constitution, the President may by order make such adaptations and modifications of such law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient, and provide that the law shall, as from such date as may be specified in the order, have effect subject to the adaptations and modifications so made, and any such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court of law. (3) Nothing in clause (2) shall be deemed— (a) to empower the President to make any adaptation or modification of any law after the expiration of three years from the commencement of this Constitution; or (b) to prevent any competent Legislature or other competent authority from repealing or amending any law adapted or modified by the President under the said clause.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Power of the President to adapt laws

amendments.description: Inserted Article 372A to empower the President to adapt laws for the purposes of state reorganization.
amendments.updated_text: (1) For the purposes of bringing the provisions of any law in force in India or in any part thereof, immediately before the commencement of the Constitution (Seventh Amendment) Act, 1956, into accord with the provisions of this Constitution as amended by that Act, the President may by order made before the 1st day of November, 1957, make such adaptations and modifications of the law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient, and provide that the law shall, as from such date as may be specified in the order, have effect subject to the adaptations and modifications so made, and any such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court of law. (2) Nothing in clause (1) shall be deemed to prevent a competent Legislature or other competent authority from repealing or amending any law adapted or modified by the President under the said clause.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Power of President to make order in respect of persons under preventive detention in certain cases
constitution_of_india.original_text: Until provision is made by Parliament under clause (7) of article 22, or until the expiration of one year from the commencement of this Constitution, whichever is earlier, the said article shall have effect as if for any reference to Parliament in clauses (4) and (7) thereof there were substituted a reference to the President and for any reference to any law made by Parliament in those clauses there were substituted a reference to an order made by the President.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Provisions as to Judges of the Federal Court and proceedings pending in the Federal Court or before His Majesty in Council
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) The Judges of the Federal Court holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the Judges of the Supreme Court and shall thereupon be entitled to such salaries and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as are provided for under article 125 in respect of the Judges of the Supreme Court. (2) All suits, appeals and proceedings, civil or criminal, pending in the Federal Court at the commencement of this Constitution shall stand removed to the Supreme Court, and the Supreme Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the same, and the judgments and orders of the Federal Court delivered or made before the commencement of this Constitution shall have the same force and effect as if they had been delivered or made by the Supreme Court. (3) Nothing in this Constitution shall operate to invalidate the exercise of jurisdiction by His Majesty in Council to dispose of appeals and petitions from, or in respect of, any judgment, decree or order of any court within the territory of India in so far as the exercise of such jurisdiction is authorised by law, and any order of His Majesty in Council made on any such appeal or petition after the commencement of this Constitution shall for all purposes have effect as if it were an order or decree made by the Supreme Court in the exercise of the jurisdiction conferred on it by this Constitution. (4) On and from the commencement of this Constitution the jurisdiction of the authority functioning as the Privy Council in a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule to dispose of appeals or petitions in respect of any judgment, decree or order of any court within that State shall cease, and all appeals and other proceedings pending before the said authority at such commencement shall stand removed to the Supreme Court, and the Supreme Court shall have jurisdiction to hear and determine the same.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Courts, authorities and officers to continue to function subject to the provisions of the Constitution
constitution_of_india.original_text: Subject to the other provisions of this Constitution, all courts of civil, criminal and revenue jurisdiction, all authorities and all officers, judicial, executive and ministerial, throughout the territory of India, shall continue to exercise their respective functions.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Provisions as to Judges of High Courts
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) Notwithstanding anything in clause (2) of article 217, the Judges of a High Court in any Province holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the Judges of the High Court in the corresponding State, and shall thereupon be entitled to such salaries and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as are provided for under article 221 in respect of the Judges of such High Court. (2) Any person who immediately before the commencement of this Constitution was holding office as a Judge of a High Court in any Province and has on such commencement elected under clause (1) to be a Judge of the High Court in any other State shall, if so appointed by the President, become a Judge of the High Court in that other State and shall thereupon be entitled to such salaries and allowances and to such rights in respect of leave of absence and pension as are provided for under article 221 in respect of the Judges of such High Court.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Provisions as to Comptroller and Auditor-General of India
constitution_of_india.original_text: The Auditor-General of India holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless he has elected otherwise, become on such commencement the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India and shall thereupon be entitled to such salaries and to such rights in respect of leave of absence, pension or age of retirement as are provided for under article 148 in respect of the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India and shall be eligible for appointment as a Judge of the Supreme Court or as a Judge of a High Court in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Provisions as to Public Service Commissions
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) The members of the Public Service Commission for the Dominion of India holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the members of the Public Service Commission for the Union and shall, notwithstanding anything in articles 316 and 317, but subject to the proviso to clause (2) of article 316, continue to hold office until the expiration of their term of office as determined under the rules which were applicable immediately before such commencement to such members. (2) The members of a Public Service Commission of a Province holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, unless they have elected otherwise, become on such commencement the members of the Public Service Commission for the corresponding State and shall, notwithstanding anything in articles 316 and 317, but subject to the proviso to clause (2) of article 316, continue to hold office until the expiration of their term of office as determined under the rules which were applicable immediately before such commencement to such members.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Special provision as to duration of Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly

amendments.description: Inserted Article 378A to provide a special provision for the duration of the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly.
amendments.updated_text: Notwithstanding anything contained in article 172, the Legislative Assembly of the State of Andhra Pradesh as constituted under the provisions of the Andhra Pradesh Legislative Assembly (Continuance) Order, 1973, shall be deemed to have been duly constituted under this Constitution and shall continue for a period of six years from the date of its constitution, and the said period of six years shall be deemed to be the period for which the said Legislative Assembly was constituted under clause (1) of article 172.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provisions as to provisional Parliament and the Speaker and Deputy Speaker thereof
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) Until both Houses of Parliament are duly constituted and summoned to meet for the first session under the provisions of this Constitution, the body functioning as the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall be the provisional Parliament and shall exercise all the powers and perform all the duties conferred by the provisions of this Constitution on the two Houses of Parliament. (2) The Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall be the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker, respectively, of the provisional Parliament. (3) Such person as the provisional Parliament may appoint shall be the Secretary to the provisional Parliament.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 379 as it was no longer necessary after the establishment of the permanent Parliament.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provision as to President
constitution_of_india.original_text: The person holding office as the President of the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, until a President is elected in accordance with the provisions of Chapter I of Part V, be the President of India.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 380 as it was no longer necessary after the election of the first President of India.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provision as to the Vice-President
constitution_of_india.original_text: The person holding office as the Vice-President of the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, until a Vice-President is elected in accordance with the provisions of Chapter I of Part V, be the Vice-President of India.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 381 as it was no longer necessary after the election of the first Vice-President of India.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provisions as to the Council of Ministers and the Attorney-General
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) The persons who immediately before the commencement of this Constitution were members of the Council of Ministers for the Dominion of India shall, on such commencement, become the members of the Council of Ministers for India and shall continue to hold office until the Prime Minister is appointed in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution and a new Council of Ministers is constituted. (2) The person holding office as the Advocate-General for the Dominion of India immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, on such commencement, become the Attorney-General for India and shall continue to hold office until the Attorney-General is appointed in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 382 as it was no longer necessary after the establishment of the permanent Council of Ministers and appointment of the Attorney-General.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provisions as to the provisional Legislatures of States
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) Until the Legislature of a State is duly constituted and summoned to meet for the first session under the provisions of this Constitution, the body functioning as the Legislature of the corresponding Province or Indian State immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall be the provisional Legislature of the State and shall exercise all the powers and perform all the duties conferred by the provisions of this Constitution on the Legislature of the State. (2) The Speaker and the Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly of a Province or the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council of a Province holding office immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall be the Speaker and the Deputy Speaker, or the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman, as the case may be, of the provisional Legislature of the corresponding State.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 383 as it was no longer necessary after the establishment of permanent State Legislatures.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provision as to Governors of States
constitution_of_india.original_text: The person holding office as the Governor or Administrator of a Province or Indian State immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, until a Governor is appointed in accordance with the provisions of Chapter II of Part VI, be the Governor of the corresponding State.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 384 as it was no longer necessary after the appointment of permanent Governors for States.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Powers of Governors and other authorities in States to continue until altered by competent authority
constitution_of_india.original_text: Until other provision is made by or in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution, the powers, duties and functions of the Governor or any other authority in any State shall be the same as those exercisable by the Governor or such authority immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, and any law in force in the State immediately before such commencement shall continue in force until altered or repealed by a competent Legislature or other competent authority.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Powers of provisional Legislatures to continue until altered by competent authority
constitution_of_india.original_text: Until other provision is made by or in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution, the powers, duties and functions of the provisional Legislature of a State shall be the same as those exercisable by the Legislature of the corresponding Province or Indian State immediately before the commencement of this Constitution, and any law in force in the State immediately before such commencement shall continue in force until altered or repealed by a competent Legislature or other competent authority.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provisions as to the Council of Ministers for States in Part B of the First Schedule
constitution_of_india.original_text: The persons who immediately before the commencement of this Constitution were members of the Council of Ministers for an Indian State specified in Part B of the First Schedule shall, on such commencement, become the members of the Council of Ministers for the corresponding State and shall continue to hold office until a new Council of Ministers is constituted in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 387 as it was no longer necessary after the reorganization of States and the establishment of permanent Councils of Ministers.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provisions as to the Advocate-General for States
constitution_of_india.original_text: The person holding office as the Advocate-General for a Province or an Indian State immediately before the commencement of this Constitution shall, until an Advocate-General is appointed in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution, be the Advocate-General for the corresponding State.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 388 as it was no longer necessary after the appointment of permanent Advocates-General for States.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Money Bills in States in Part B of the First Schedule
constitution_of_india.original_text: Until provision is made by the Legislature of a State specified in Part B of the First Schedule for the introduction, consideration and passing of Money Bills, the procedure for the introduction, consideration and passing of Money Bills in the provisional Legislature of such State shall be the same as that followed in the Legislature of the corresponding Indian State immediately before the commencement of this Constitution.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 389 as it was no longer necessary after the establishment of permanent legislative procedures in States.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Provisions as to the filling of casual vacancies in the provisional Parliament and provisional Legislatures of States
constitution_of_india.original_text: Casual vacancies in the provisional Parliament or in the provisional Legislature of a State shall be filled in the same manner as casual vacancies were filled in the Constituent Assembly of the Dominion of India or, as the case may be, in the Legislature of the corresponding Province or Indian State immediately before the commencement of this Constitution.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 390 as it was no longer necessary after the establishment of permanent procedures for filling vacancies in Parliament and State Legislatures.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Power of the President to remove difficulties
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) If any difficulty arises in giving effect to the provisions of this Constitution during the period in which the provisional Parliament or the provisional Legislature of a State is functioning, the President may, by order, make such provisions, not inconsistent with the purposes of this Constitution, as appear to him to be necessary or expedient for removing the difficulty. (2) No order shall be made under this article after the expiration of three years from the commencement of this Constitution.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 391 as it was no longer necessary after the establishment of permanent constitutional institutions and the expiry of the transitional period.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Power of the President to adapt laws
constitution_of_india.original_text: (1) For the purpose of bringing the provisions of any law in force in the territory of India into accord with the provisions of this Constitution, the President may by order make such adaptations and modifications of such law, whether by way of repeal or amendment, as may be necessary or expedient, and provide that the law shall, as from such date as may be specified in the order, have effect subject to the adaptations and modifications so made, and any such adaptation or modification shall not be questioned in any court of law. (2) No order shall be made under this article after the expiration of two years from the commencement of this Constitution.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 392 as it was no longer necessary after the period for presidential adaptations of laws had expired and permanent legislative mechanisms were in place.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Repealed] Short title
constitution_of_india.original_text: This Constitution may be called the Constitution of India.

amendments.description: Repealed Article 393 as the short title was incorporated elsewhere, and a standalone article was deemed unnecessary.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Commencement
constitution_of_india.original_text: This article and articles 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 60, 324, 366, 367, 379, 380, 388, 391, 392 and 393 shall come into force at once, and the remaining provisions of this Constitution shall come into force on the twenty-sixth day of January, 1950, which day is referred to in this Constitution as the commencement of this Constitution.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Authoritative text in the Hindi language

amendments.description: Inserted Article 394A to provide for the authoritative text of the Constitution in the Hindi language, including translations and publication.
amendments.updated_text: (1) The President shall cause to be published under his authority,— (a) the translation of this Constitution in the Hindi language, signed by the members of the Constituent Assembly, with such modifications as may be necessary to bring it in conformity with the language, style and terminology adopted in the authoritative texts of Central Acts in the Hindi language, and incorporating therein all the amendments of this Constitution made before such publication; and (b) the translation in the Hindi language of every amendment of this Constitution made in the English language. (2) The translation of this Constitution and of every amendment thereof published under clause (1) shall be construed to have the same meaning as the original thereof and if any difficulty arises in so construing any part of such translation, the President shall cause the same to be revised suitably. (3) The translation of this Constitution and of every amendment thereof published under this article shall be deemed to be, for all purposes, the authoritative text thereof in the Hindi language.

constitution_of_india.article_name: Repeals
constitution_of_india.original_text: The Indian Independence Act, 1947, and the Government of India Act, 1935, together with all enactments amending or supplementing the latter Act, but not including the Abolition of Privy Council Jurisdiction Act, 1949, are hereby repealed.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Not an Article] First Schedule
constitution_of_india.original_text: The First Schedule lists the States and the territories of India.

amendments.description: Amended the First Schedule to reflect the reorganization of States under the States Reorganisation Act, 1956, updating the list of States and Union Territories.
amendments.updated_text: The First Schedule lists the reorganized States and Union Territories of India, as updated by the States Reorganisation Act, 1956.

amendments.description: Amended the First Schedule to reflect the reorganization of Jammu and Kashmir into two Union Territories: Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh, following the abrogation of Article 370.
amendments.updated_text: The First Schedule lists the States and Union Territories of India, including the Union Territories of Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh, as updated by the Jammu and Kashmir Reorganisation Act, 2019.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Not an Article] Second Schedule
constitution_of_india.original_text: The Second Schedule contains provisions regarding the emoluments, allowances, privileges, and so on of the President, the Governors, the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People, the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States, the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council, the Judges of the Supreme Court, the Judges of the High Courts, and the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India.

amendments.description: Amended the Second Schedule to update provisions regarding emoluments and privileges in light of the reorganization of States and abolition of Part B States.
amendments.updated_text: The Second Schedule contains updated provisions regarding the emoluments, allowances, privileges, and so on of the President, the Governors, the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the House of the People, the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Council of States, the Speaker and Deputy Speaker of the Legislative Assembly, the Chairman and Deputy Chairman of the Legislative Council, the Judges of the Supreme Court, the Judges of the High Courts, and the Comptroller and Auditor-General of India, as revised following the States Reorganisation Act, 1956.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Not an Article] Third Schedule
constitution_of_india.original_text: The Third Schedule contains the Forms of Oaths or Affirmations for the President, Ministers, Judges, Members of Parliament, Members of State Legislatures, and other officials.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Not an Article] Fourth Schedule
constitution_of_india.original_text: The Fourth Schedule contains provisions regarding the allocation of seats in the Council of States (Rajya Sabha) to States and Union Territories.

amendments.description: Amended the Fourth Schedule to revise the allocation of seats in the Council of States to reflect the reorganization of States.
amendments.updated_text: The Fourth Schedule contains updated provisions regarding the allocation of seats in the Council of States (Rajya Sabha) to the reorganized States and Union Territories, as revised by the States Reorganisation Act, 1956.

amendments.description: Amended the Fourth Schedule to update the allocation of seats in the Council of States following the reorganization of Jammu and Kashmir into two Union Territories.
amendments.updated_text: The Fourth Schedule contains provisions regarding the allocation of seats in the Council of States (Rajya Sabha) to States and Union Territories, including the Union Territories of Jammu and Kashmir and Ladakh, as updated by the Jammu and Kashmir Reorganisation Act, 2019.

constitution_of_india.article_name: [Not an Article] Fifth Schedule
constitution_of_india.original_text: The Fifth Schedule contains provisions regarding the administration and control of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes.
